Legal_Issue: Whether the RPD's state protection analysis was unreasonable, particularly in its reliance on selected evidence indicating adequate state protection for Roma people in Hungary
Outcome: Decision quashed, case remanded for reconsideration
Procedural_Context: Judicial review application under subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Evidence_Type: Evidence indicating adequate state protection for Roma people in Hungary
Legal_Provision: Subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution as Roma in Hungary due to inadequate state protection
Key_Factor_in_Determination: RPD's selective analysis of evidence on state protection
Application_Error: Selective use of evidence, ignoring inconsistencies and general ineffectiveness of state protection
Evidence_Ignored: Inconsistencies and broader evidence of ineffective state protection for Roma in Hungary
Legal_Standard: Claimant must demonstrate inability to obtain state protection or that home state cannot reasonably provide it
Application_Factor: Applicants did not take all reasonable steps to seek state protection
Governing_Rule_or_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act – state protection requirement
Cause_of_Refusal: Presumption of adequate state protection in Hungary despite evidence to the contrary
Evidentiary_Issues: Selective reliance on evidence, failure to consider contradictory reports
Legal_Defense_or_Challenge: Judicial review challenging unreasonableness of RPD decision
Omission_Type: Failure to disclose previous asylum refusals or lack of full cooperation with protection authorities

Legal_Issue: Whether the RPD's analysis of state protection in Hungary was unreasonable, particularly regarding adequacy of police response to Roma persecution
Application_Facts: Applicants faced violence and persecution in Hungary; reported some incidents to police but not others due to fear and mistrust
Decision_Outcome: Initial denial of refugee status based on presumed adequate state protection
Remedy_Requested: Grant of refugee protection in Canada
Court_Ruling: RPD’s assessment found unreasonable due to selective interpretation of evidence
Defendant_Behavior: Remaining in Canada beyond authorized period
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution based on Roma ethnicity
Legal_Standard: Claimant must show inability to access effective state protection
Assessment_Factor: Pattern of ineffective state protection for Roma despite formal mechanisms
Evidence_Used: Incidents of violence, police reports, country condition reports
Application_Basis: Persecution risk due to ethnic identity and lack of state protection
Evidence_Assessed: Police responsiveness and systemic failures in protecting Roma
Relief_Sought: Refugee status and lawful residency in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: RPD ignored broader patterns of ineffective protection
Outcome: Decision quashed, matter remanded for reconsideration
Harm_Assessment: Risk of continued persecution if returned to Hungary
Cause_Description: Fleeing persecution in Hungary due to Roma identity
Evidence_Handling: Selective consideration of positive developments while disregarding persistent discrimination
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration status violation due to overstaying
Jurisdictional_Issue: Canadian jurisdiction over foreign persecution claims
Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient weight given to lived experiences of Roma persecution
Decision_Rationale: Assumption that Hungary provides adequate protection despite documented shortcomings
Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to holistically assess evidence on state protection

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Legal_Issue: Whether the RPD's state protection analysis was unreasonable, specifically if Hungary provides adequate state protection for Roma individuals
Outcome: RPD decision quashed, case remanded for reconsideration
Procedural_Context: Judicial review under subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Evidence_Type: Reports of persecution, police responses, systemic issues in Hungary
Legal_Provision: Subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution as Roma in Hungary due to inadequate state protection
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Board's reliance on selective evidence of Hungarian efforts while ignoring broader evidence of failure
Application_Error: Failure to consider full scope of evidence on state protection for Roma
Evidence_Ignored: Broader evidence showing inadequate state protection for Roma in Hungary
Legal_Standard: Claimant must demonstrate inability to obtain or lack of reasonable expectation of state protection
Application_Factor: Systemic lack of trust in Hungarian authorities among Roma community
Decision_Outcome: Refusal of work permit and refugee claim based on presumption of adequate protection
Decision_Review_Issue: Unreasonable assessment of country conditions and state protection
Cause_of_Refusal: Presumption that Hungary can provide adequate protection to Roma individuals
Evidentiary_Issues: Selective reliance on isolated examples of state action without contextual analysis
Legal_Defense_or_Challenge: Judicial review challenging reasonableness of RPD decision
Omission_Type: Failure to fully establish efforts to seek protection in home country
